dt: {bc}to think about something carefully and thoroughly
{bc}to think or say (something) in a thoughtful way

dt.t: "I could sell the house," she {it}mused{/it}, "but where would I go?"

pt: {sc}ponder{/sc} {sc}meditate{/sc} {sc}muse{/sc} {sc}ruminate{/sc} mean to consider or examine attentively or deliberately. {sc}ponder{/sc} implies a careful weighing of a problem or, often, prolonged inconclusive thinking about a matter.
{sc}meditate{/sc} implies a definite focusing of one's thoughts on something so as to understand it deeply.
{sc}muse{/sc} suggests a more or less focused daydreaming as in remembrance.
{sc}ruminate{/sc} implies going over the same matter in one's thoughts again and again but suggests little of either purposive thinking or rapt absorption.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}muser{/it} to gape, idle, muse, from Old French {it}*mus{/it} mouth of an animal, from Medieval Latin {it}musus{/it}
shortdef: to become absorbed in thought; especially : to think about something carefully and thoroughly
to think or say (something) in a thoughtful way

dt: {bc}a state of deep thought or dreamy abstraction

dt.t: thrown into a {wi}muse{/wi} by the book she was reading

shortdef: a state of deep thought or dreamy abstraction

dt: {bc}any of the nine sister goddesses in Greek mythology presiding over song and poetry and the arts and sciences

dt.t: Clio is the Greek {it}Muse{/it} of history.
The writer's beloved wife was his {wi}muse{/wi}.

et: Middle English, from Middle French, from Latin {it}Musa{/it}, from Greek {it}Mousa{/it}
shortdef: any of the nine sister goddesses in Greek mythology presiding over song and poetry and the arts and sciences
a source of inspiration; especially : a guiding genius
